_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water.  The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination.  Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water.  The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP) also uses chlorine for drinking water disinfection purposes at the Green Verdugo Reservoir Complex to protect public health per state and federal water quality standards. Storing and handling large quantities of chlorine can create hazardous situations. The LADWP takes safety obligations in storing and using chlorine as seriously as it takes in providing safe drinking water.



The LADWP Green Verdugo Reservoir Complex Chlorination Station (GVCS) chlorine handling process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements. The facilities subject to the EPA and the CalARP regulations are required to prepare and update Risk Management Plans (RMPs). The RMP is to include policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility and the actions, which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.



The LADWP prepared and submitted RMPs for the GVCS in June 1999, June 2004, June 2009, and June 2014. The LADWP prepared Program Level 2 RMPs in 1999 and 2004 because GVCS is not subject to PSM standard.. However, in the excess of caution, the LADWP prepared a Program Level 3 RMP in 2009. The 2014 update of the 2009 RMP also demonstrated compliance with the Program Level 3 requirements.  This document is an update of the 2014 RMP for the Green Verdugo Reservoir Complex Chlorination Station. 



The following information is specifically required in the RMP Update Executive Summary: 



?    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.

?    General facility and regulated substances

information.

?    Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.

?    Five-year accident history summary.

?    Emergency response program summary.

?    Planned changes to improve safety.



The above information for the Green Verdugo Reservoir Complex Chlorination Station is provided below.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The LADWP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices. All applicable requirements of the State of California and the EPA's Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  



The LADWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials, which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA and the CalARP Program Emergency Response Program Requirements. The LADWP has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for the Green Verdugo Reservoir Complex Chlorination Station to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency. The Emergency Response Plan has been coordinated with the local response agency (City of Los Angeles Fire Department). The Green Verdugo Reservoir Complex Chlorination Station has an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.



General Facility and Regulated Substance Information



The Green Verdugo Chlorination Station is located adjacent to the Green-Verdugo reservoir, on the west portion of Tujunga Ranch, at 10320 Sunland Boulevard in Sunland, California.  The Green Verdugo Chlorination Station serves to chlorinate water outflow from, and the stored water in, the Green Verdugo reservoir.

After disinfection, water from the chlorination station is distributed for both domestic and industrial consumption in the Sunland area.  The station consists of a chlorination room (with a mini-scrubber), an instrument room, and a pump operations room. The facility currently stores chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the EPA and CalARP Program rules.  There is a maximum of four chlorine ton containers at the chlorination station.  All four ton containers can be connected to the chlorination process to feed chlorine gas. The ton container is the largest vessel (container) online. The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the Green Verdugo Chlorination Station at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the EPA and the CalARP regulations. It also exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the federal and CalOSHA PSM Standards. However, the facility is normally unstaffed and water treatment operators visit the facility daily and respond to any trouble alarms that may occur.  Therefore, the LADWP Green Verdugo Chlorination Station is not subject to the federal or the California OSHA PSM standards. 



As mentioned above, a maximum of four chlorine ton containers are stored at the chlorination station. All the four ton containers rest on load cell scales, which allow the operators to monitor the chlorine weight remaining in the ton container. Chlorine gas is withdrawn from the ton container through a vacuum regulating valve, which is installed directly on the ton container angle valve.  Chlorine gas is pulled under vacuum from the vacuum regulating valve through plastic tubing and the chlorine PVC header lines to one or more of the five chlorinators provided at the chlorination station. In case of rupture of the plastic tubing connecting the ton container to the header lines, air would be drawn in rather than chlorine being released, and the vacuum regulator would shut down the chlorine supply at the ton container angle valve, operating as a

shut-off valve. From the chlorinator, the gas is pulled by vacuum to injectors located in a cabinet on the exterior wall of the station.  In the injectors, chlorine gas is dissolved into mixing water to form a concentrated solution.  This solution is then piped into diffusers to treat the reservoir and the pump station discharge line.  



Chlorine residual analyzers continuously monitor free and total chlorine residual at all feed points.  Motorized valves are provided downstream of each vacuum regulating valve to shut off chlorine feed from the ton containers if the control system senses zero water flow in the pipelines.



Chlorine leak detectors are provided inside the chlorine building, which alarm locally as well as at the LADWP's Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) Control Room at Sylmar.



A dry media chlorine "mini-scrubber" unit (MS) has been installed at the GVCS. The MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel working in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release from the pressure safety relief valve installed on the piping between the vacuum regulator and the chlorinator. The mini-scrubber can neutralize up to 25 lbs of chlorine, and the media manufacturer specifies chlorine removal to less than 5 parts per billion. The mini-scrubber is activated automatically at a chlorine concentration of 1 ppm.



In the event power is lost at this chlorination facility, an alarm will alert the LAAFP control room. The chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences.

The facility is normally unoccupied; water treatment operators visit the facility daily.  A response team coordinated from the LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) responds to any trouble alarms, which may occur.  Access to the facility is through gates that are kept locked at all times.



Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The LADWP accidental release preventi

on program is based on the following key elements:



?    Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.

?    Comprehensive process safety information/safety information that are readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.

?    Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.

?    Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.

?    State-of-the-art process and safety equipment.

?    Accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the station operators.

?    High level training for the operators and maintenance staff.

?    A State of California Water Treatment Facility Staff Certification is required to operate the station.

?    An incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.



Chemical-specific prevention steps for the chlorination system include the following: availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply; awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine; presence of chlorine detectors with remote monitoring; and a chlorine mini-scrubber.



Process and Chemical Safety Information



Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and Safety Data Sheets.



Equipment safety information has been compiled on the chlorination process. Specifications for the chlorination process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details (such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the chlorination facility) are on file at the facility.  The LADWP also has procedures in place that are triggered to upd

ate process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.



Process Hazard Analysis 



In 1993, a detailed hazard review/PHA was conducted for the chlorination system equipment and procedures.  The 1993 hazard review/PHA was further reviewed in April 1999. In February 2004, a hazard review/PHA was again performed for the whole chlorination system. The 2004 hazard review/PHA for the facility was further reviewed in February 2009 and February 2014. A PHA was again performed for the GVCS on February 8, 2019, and will be updated again within a five-year period or whenever there will be a major change in the process. A list of recommended actions was developed in February 2019 to further improve the chlorine safety. All of these recommendations are being evaluated for implementation. The LADWP staff will document the completion of the recommended actions.



A seismic assessment, including the walkthrough on February 14, 2019 was completed for the chlorination station in April 2019. Based on the April 2019 seismic assessment of the chlorination station, a set of recommendations was made to further improve the safety of the chlorination station during the future earthquakes. All of these recommendations are being evaluated for implementation. The seismic assessment was performed following the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) Region 1 guidance document. 



Operating Procedures



The LADWP has prepared written operating procedures for Green Verdugo Reservoir Complex Chlorination Station that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to chlorination process. They are consistent with the chlorine safety information. Written operating procedures included in the facility's Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Manual are as follows:



?    Delivery of Chlorine.

?    Ton Container Connections.

?    Initial Startup Procedure.

?    Normal Operation.

?    Normal Shutdown.

?    Temporary Operations.

?    Emerge

ncy Operations.

?    Emergency Shutdown.

?    Startup Following Emergency Shutdown.



Training 



The LADWP ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the chlorination process, and each employee newly assigned to this process, is trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above. LADWP employee training documentation files include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the chlorination process. The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely perform the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  Employee training includes as a minimum the following elements:



?    Safety Information.

?    Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.

?    Maintenance Procedures.

?    Operating Procedures for the chlorine system.

?    RMP Program contents.

?    Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.



Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the chlorination process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures. In addition, the LADWP ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after major modifications.  



Contractors



The LADWP Contractor's procedures specify the information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on or near the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules.  The LADWP provides information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes. 

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program



The LADWP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to

the chlorination systems that require a Management of Change (MOC) procedure implementation.  The required conditions prior to startup include the following:



?    Construction and/or equipment are in accordance with design specifications.

?    Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.

?    A PHA has been performed for any new facilities and recommendations have been resolved or implemented prior to startup.

?    At modified facilities, MOC requirements have been met.

?    Training of each operating and maintenance employee involved in the process is complete.



These procedures ensure that no new and/or new/significantly modified process will startup and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process before the pre-startup safety review. This constitutes a final check that the process and equipment are ready to go and that the recommendations of the PHA have been implemented or adequately addressed. This will ensure that the design and construction of a new or modified process is safely executed and that the facility is prepared to operate it. 



Mechanical integrity procedures for the plant ensure that written maintenance procedures are implemented and documented, including training of maintenance personnel.



Maintenance 



The LADWP operates a MAXIMO, an asset management program that generates a preventive maintenance work order at a designated frequency. Description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order. In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the O&M Manuals as follows: Preventive maintenance schedules are provided which summarize inspection, test, and maintenance schedules on a daily, weekly, bi-monthly, monthly, biannual, and annual, every 2 to 10 years, and as-needed basis. These procedures allow the operator to rapidly review what maintenance is necessary. The schedules are supplemental to the log sheets on-site and provide a summary and quick refer

ence to manufacturer's O&M manuals. A maintenance log book is provided on-site for Operator quick reference.



The LADWP documents inspection, testing, and maintenance of chlorination equipment and assures the performance is performed in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups.



Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 



Hot work refers to work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark producing operations. The hot work procedures require the issuance of a hot work permit whenever it is conducted on or near the chlorination process and other areas deemed appropriate as described in these procedures. Fire prevention and protection systems are in place before a hot work permit is issued. The permit indicates the dates the work is authorized for, the location, and specific operational requirements, and it is kept on file in the administrative office. 



The LADWP Management of Change procedures include steps required to be taken by plant personnel before implementing changes to chlorination equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions.  Training, process safety information, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are updated according to the changes made.



Internal Compliance Audits



The LADWP has been certifying every three years (or earlier) that compliance with Program 2 Prevention Program requirements for the chlorination station is met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. Starting June 2009, the LADWP certified compliance with Program 3 Prevention Program requirements. The two most recent audit reports and a list of the recommendations are retained in the LADWP's files.



The compliance audit consists of separating the RMP program elements or sections, and auditing each element to determine compliance and effectiveness. For each internal audit, the audit team completes a Compliance Audit Certification Page and a C

ompliance Audit Checklist. The Compliance Audit Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, and certification by the audit leader. The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contain questions that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:



?    Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.

?    On-Site Conditions: The audit team reviews the program elements based on observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.

?    Interviews:  The program elements are evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.



Compliance Auditor will record RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist.



Incident Investigation



The LADWP incident investigation procedures describe incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant personnel. The incident investigation is started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event. The LADWP promptly addresses and resolves all recommendations and implements the recommendations in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence. All incident investigation reports are retained in the LADWP's file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.



Five-year Accident History Summary



No chlorine releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the Green Verdugo Reservoir Complex Chlorination Station during the last five years.



Emergency Response Program Summary



The LADWP is a first responder, its employees respond to chlorine accidental releases. In the event an accidental release that could result in offsite consequences occurs, external resources, such as the City of Los An

geles Fire Department will also be solicited to respond.  



As part of the emergency response program, the LADWP has developed and implemented an emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. The following elements are included:



(a)    Emergency response plan, maintained at the Green Verdugo Reservoir Complex Chlorination Station and at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) containing:



?    Organizational structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various LADWP personnel.

?    Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations.

?    Details of the training programs for all employees involved with the chlorination process, contractor training, and medical surveillance of LADWP personnel who respond to chlorine release.

?    Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the LADWP.

?    Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.

?    Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information on emergency health care.

?    Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.



(b)    Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. 

(c)    Training in relevant procedures for all employees involved with the chlorination process.

(d)    Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Chlorination Station



Based on the February 2014 PHA, a few recommendations were made for the GVCS. All the above recommendations have been evaluated by the LADWP. Additionally, eight recommendations to further improve chlorine safety were identified in February 2019, when PHA was again performed for the GVCS.



Based on the February 2014 seismic as

sessment, two recommendations were made for the GVCS. All the above recommendations have been evaluated by the LADWP. Additionally, three recommendations to further improve chlorine safety were identified in April 2019, when seismic assessment was again performed for the GVCS. 



It is expected that all the above 2019 recommendations will be evaluated and implemented by August 2021. The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of the chlorination system.
